title: ASX to rise, S&P 500 edges higher, $A drops
summary: Australian shares are poised to open higher as the S&P 500 pushed higher. Fed officials affirm no rush to tighten policy.
author: Timothy Moore

heading: Australian shares are set to open higher, with the S&P 500 edging modestly higher though losing momentum as the session progressed.
JPMorgan boss Jamie Dimon told shareholders he sees the US economy booming for at least two more years.
Separately, the latest minutes from the Federal Reserve’s policy meeting reaffirm that there’s no plan to rush to tighten monetary policy.
ASX futures were up 36 points or 0.5 per cent to 6935 near 7am. The currency slid towards a US75¢ handle, down 0.7 per cent. The yield on the US 10-year note edged up 2 basis points to 1.67 per cent.

In New York, shares closed mixed with both the S&P 500 and the Dow edging higher and the Nasdaq slipping. The S&P 500 rose 0.2 per cent; the Dow was up 0.1 per cent; and, the Nasdaq was down 0.1 per cent.
Five of the S&P’s 11 industry sectors were higher paced by a 0.7 per cent gain in communication services and a 0.5 per cent rise in information technology.

The latest Fed meeting minutes “underscored that the Fed is willing to run the economy hot”, Oxford Economics’ Kathy Bostjancic said in a note. “The Fed will be extremely patient in raising the policy rate.”

TD Securities said the minutes “echoed” with an optimism tone that is justified given the improvement in recent economic data. Since the meeting, the economic momentum has only gotten better, it added.
“We are clearly seeing the economic recovery take hold. This is why an increasing number of Fed members have upgraded their forecast and brought forward the start of the rate hiking cycle.
“Based on the expectation that the economy will be fully recovered in 2023, it would be reasonable for the Fed to start raising its policy rate at that time.”
All of that optimism continues to encourage economists to lift their bets on the US outlook.

LPL Financial overnight lifted its forecasts: “An accelerating vaccine rollout, American’s desire to resume somewhat normal lives, and massive stimulus set the stage for booming growth in the US economy this year. Our 2021 US GDP growth forecast goes from 5—5.5 per cent to 6.25—6.75 per cent.”

For the S&P 500, LPL said it was lifting its earnings per share target to between $US175 and $US177.50 from $US170 previously; though it left its year-end fair value target for the S&P 500 Index unchanged at 4050—4100 “for now in anticipation of lower stock valuations as interest rates rise”.
The S&P 500 closed at 4079.95 in New York overnight.

United States: US economy could boom at least two more years: Dimon: The JPMorgan boss foresees a Goldilocks moment, where growth is fast and sustained while inflation ticks up gently.

Risk of Tesla shares is not owning them: Morgan Stanley: Over the long term, “auto investors face greater risk not owning Tesla shares in their portfolio than owning Tesla shares in their portfolio”, the broker argues.

Bank of America’s view on the US reaching ‘herd immunity’: “We have increasingly argued, however, that overlooked in the debate is whether we need to reach the textbook level of population immunity (65-80 per cent) to more broadly open the economy-an outlook, we think, remains justified by the current trends given the evidence of vaccine efficacy.
“To be fair, we recognise it is early with vaccine supplies still constrained globally and the potential emergence of even more challenging variants possible.

“But with production ramping, still favourable vaccine acceptance rates, and continued stream of positive real-world updates-including robust 6-month Pfizer/BioNTech data-we remain hopeful for significant progress on a return to normal in the US by late-spring with herd immunity to follow” in the final three months of the year.
Europe: Britain scraps AstraZeneca jabs for the under-30s on blood clot fears: If the regulators’ concerns spill over Down Under, it may have repercussions for Australia’s vaccination program.
European stocks were little changed and closed just short of record highs on Wednesday, with healthcare shares among top decliners.
The pan-European STOXX 600 index edged 0.1 per cent lower, trading just below the record closing peak of 435.26 points on Tuesday. Healthcare stocks fell 0.8 per cent, leading sectoral declines.

UK’s exporter-heavy FTSE 100 gained 0.9 per cent as a weaker pound lifted the dollar earners, while the domestically focussed midcap index hit a record high as Britain began the roll-out of Moderna’s COVID-19 vaccine.

“It appears that while the UK blue chip index, and its mid-cap sibling, enjoy the optimism surrounding the country’s post-COVID comeback, sterling has been saddled with concerns over the vaccine programme,” said Connor Campbell, an analyst at Spreadex.

A rebound in economically sensitive sectors such as banks, energy and automakers pushed European stocks to pre-pandemic levels earlier this week, as investors bet on a strong global economic recovery, driven by vaccines and unprecedented stimulus measures.

A final reading of IHS Markit’s Purchasing Managers’ Index showed euro zone business activity returned to growth in March, underpinned by a record expansion in the manufacturing sector and as the service industry coped with new lockdowns better than expected.
Asia: China’s main equity gauges fell on Wednesday with consumer firms dragging the market lower, as investors continued to worry that strong economic data could lead to possible policy tightening.
At the close, the Shanghai Composite index was down 0.1 per cent at 3479.63. The blue-chip CSI300 index was down 0.7 per cent.

At the close of trade in Hong Kong, the Hang Seng index was down 263.94 points or 0.9 per cent at 28,674.80. The index had closed at its highest level in more than a week on Apr. 1 before a five-day holiday weekend.
The Hang Seng China Enterprises index fell 1.3 per cent to 11,070.58.
Index heavyweight Tencent dropped 3.8 per cent and was the biggest drag on the Hang Seng for the day. Its fall pushed the TECH index down 1.4 per cent and the IT sector down 2.4 per cent.
Currencies: China’s control of bitcoin mining terrifies investors: New research suggests coal-powered China controls around 75 per cent of bitcoin mining, which is set to consume as much energy as Italy by 2024.

BlackRock wary of the Fed’s optimism: “With economic growth forecasts accelerating, and with inflation set to rise markedly for a handful of cyclical influences, policymakers risk looking increasingly out of touch with reality, which threatens their credibility.”
And BlackRock says investors need to be cautious: “Nominal US Treasury yields have surged over recent weeks with realised volatility for these ‘risk-free’ assets spiking.

“The ‘smooth functioning’ of US financial markets that is thought to be an unspoken third mandate of the Federal Reserve has diminished markedly over that same timeframe. In our view, this may be leading to diminished trading liquidity and a breakdown in many traditionally reliable cross-asset correlations (for instance, the long-term correlation between stocks and bonds has flipped).”
Commodities: Asia’s benchmark iron ore futures rose on Wednesday, as record steel prices in China prompted investors to make tentative bets, despite production cuts in the country’s steelmaking hub.
The most-traded September iron ore on China’s Dalian Commodity Exchange ended the daytime trading session 1.7per cent higher at 993.50 yuan ($US151.94) a tonne.
Iron ore’s front-month May contract on the Singapore Exchange advanced 1.5 per cent to $US164.05 a tonne by 0709 GMT.
Spot iron ore from top supplier Australia for delivery to China traded at $US168.50 a tonne on Tuesday, according to SteelHome consultancy.
“Chinese government restrictions continue to be supportive for prices,” ING commodity strategists said in a note.
“Steel mills in (Tangshan) would need to make specific data related to production parameters and pollution available on a government platform by month-end.”
Australian sharemarket: ASX rises 0.6pc to touch a 13-month high: Shares in Australian blue chips rose for the fourth straight session on Wednesday, sending the S&P/ASX 200 benchmark to its highest level since February 2020.

Chanticleer: Canva’s founders quietly show path to Nasdaq: Canva’s soaring valuation is a tribute to the strategic moves made long ago by its founders to be embedded in the Silicon Valley ecosystem. It is a passport to Nasdaq nirvana.
